DBS surgery

What is deep brain stimulation?

Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) is a surgical procedure that involves placing a small device, similar to a pacemaker, under the skin of your chest. This device is connected to thin wires that go into specific parts of your brain. It sends electrical signals to help control the tremors, offering relief to people with essential tremor when medications don’t work well enough.

Who DBS is for

DBS is not the first line of treatment for essential tremor. It’s generally considered when medications like beta-blockers don’t control the tremor enough or cause too many side effects. If your tremors are making daily tasks like eating, writing, or dressing difficult despite medication, your doctor might suggest exploring DBS as an option.

How DBS works

During the DBS procedure, a neurosurgeon places electrodes in the part of your brain responsible for movement. These electrodes are connected to a device implanted under your skin, usually near your collarbone. The device sends electrical signals that help control the shaking by interfering with the brain signals causing it.

The procedure

The operation is done in two parts:

  1. Installing the electrodes: While you’re under local anesthesia (awake but numb), the surgeon places the electrodes in your brain. Your feedback during this part is crucial to ensure the electrodes are in the best position to control the tremors.

  2. Installing the device: In the second part of the surgery, you’ll be under general anesthesia (asleep). The surgeon implants the battery-operated device under your skin and connects it to the electrodes with wires.

Risks and side effects

Like any surgery, DBS has some risks, such as infection, bleeding, and issues related to anesthesia. Some people also experience temporary tingling, balance issues, or speech problems, but these often improve over time.

What to expect after surgery

Call 911 or go the ER now if you have:

  • An elevated temperature or fever
  • Redness, swelling, or increased pain around the incision sites
  • A sudden onset of severe headache
  • New or worsening cognitive difficulties or confusion
  • A sudden change in vision or speech

After the procedure, you’ll need several follow-up visits to fine-tune the device settings. You’ll also continue to see your doctor to monitor how well the DBS is controlling your tremors and make any needed adjustments.

Success rate

Many people see a significant improvement in their tremors after DBS. However, it’s essential to have realistic expectations. While the procedure can substantially reduce tremors, it doesn’t cure essential tremor and may not completely eliminate all symptoms.
